article.description: The fifth-ranked Panthers turned Brandin Knight's playmaking and Jaron Brown's dunks into a big early lead and didn't let up in Wednesday night's 69-46 victory.
article.headline: Red Flash no match for No. 5 Panthers
article.linkText: Pittsburgh overwhelms St. Francis, Pa., moves to 2-0
article.story:
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- St. Francis, Pa., was 0-25 against Pittsburgh. This wasn't the team to pick for the Red Flash to try to get victory No. 2 this season.

The fifth-ranked Panthers turned Brandin Knight's playmaking and Jaron Brown's dunks into a big early lead and didn't let up in Wednesday night's 69-46 victory.

Knight, a third-team All-American who had offseason surgery on his right knee, is fighting with his shooting, but there's nothing wrong with the rest of his game.

Knight was 4-of-11 while scoring 10 points, but he just missed a
triple-double with nine assists and eight rebounds.

   "I'm excited about Brandin's line,'' Pitt coach Ben Howland
said. "We really, truly want the big guys to get the rebounds. But
the truth is our point guard is really good, and he goes in there
and gets rebounds.''

The Panthers (2-0) opened a 14-3 lead with 7½ minutes gone, off
a succession of Knight feeds on fast breaks. The smaller, slower
Red Flash (1-1) didn't reach double figures until 4:52 remained in
the first half.

Pitt shot 47.4 percent despite making only 5-of-21 3-pointers.
The Panthers went 22-of-36 inside the 3-point line.

"I'm just not feeling it with my shots right now. I had three
shots that went in and then rattled out,'' said Knight, who is
11-of-24 shooting in two games. "But I'm going to stay confident.
I don't feel I'm going to continue to miss those shots, and I'm
going to continue to shoot them.''

Pitt not only is 26-0 against St. Francis, located about 75
miles east of Pittsburgh, it is 53-0 against Northeast Conference
schools. The Panthers have won 19 consecutive non-conference home
games since a 64-60 loss to Virginia Commonwealth in December 1999.

"They're a legitimate top-five team,'' St. Francis coach Bobby Jones said. "They've got excellent size and a great point guard and excellent experience. We kept our perspective going into this game, and our guys didn't quit. But I wouldn't want to play five teams a year like them.''

Pittsburgh, coming off a school-record 29-victory season, was
pressed in its opener by city rival Duquesne before pulling away at
the end for an 82-67 victory, but St. Francis never was in the game.

The Panthers led by 16 points at the half, then went on a 10-0 run after St. Francis scored the opening basket of the second half to make it 45-19. They cruised the rest of the way as Howland made numerous substitutions.

The Panthers again had the offensive balance that was their
trademark last season, with freshman guard Carl Krauser coming off
the bench for 13 points, Julius Page adding 11 and Brown scoring
10.

Erick Wills hit five 3-pointers and scored 17 points for St.
Francis, which opened its season by beating Howard.

The attendance for the second game in Pitt's new Petersen Events Center was 8,686, about 3,500 below capacity, even though all seats were sold. Pitt students are on holiday break, so fans were allowed to vacate their upper-level seats and occupy the students' 1,500 courtside seats.
